comments:
When starting Eclipse SDK 3.1 by double-clicking startup.jar under WinXP,
Eclipse will fail to start, if you have jmat_5.0.jar file in "ext" folder of
your JRE "lib" folder, that Eclipse uses to run. Simply removing this jar file
solves the problem.

Putting random jars in the ext is not a good practice.
In this particular case it seems to me that the problem is caused by the
inclusion in jmat of classes like org/jdom and others which will likely cause
conflict with classes from the JRE.

I agree with Pascal.  But I would still like to see an error log or console 
output.  The only code that should have access to ext classloader is the 
startup.jar.  It should not effect the rest of eclipse.

From bug reporter:

There is no log. I just double-click startup.jar, it starts loading (i hear 
hard drive working and I get clock icon above mouse cursor), and that's it, it 
stops in 10 seconds. If I type startup.jar from console, it loads something 
(hard drive noise...) and then prints then prompt for new command, as if 
startup.jar was executed and finished. There is absolutely nothing it prints 
it out.

I don't know if it relates to another problem:

when I double-click eclipse.exe it doesn't start, but produces a log

Therefore the only way for me launch eclipse is through startup.jar.

I just started using it this Tuesday, so I don't know much about it :-) But 
it's really great, thank you so much!!! Real-time compiler is grand!

Cheers,
Kostya.

I imagine jmat has a META-INF\services\javax.xml.persers.SAXParserFactory file 
which specifies the org.apache.xerces.jaxp.SAXParserFactoryImpl class.  This 
will cause problems when JAXP API tries to create a SAXParserFactory because 
the org.apache.xerces.jaxp.SAXParserFactoryImpl class is nowhere to be found.

The root of the problem is the fact that JAXP uses the context classloader to 
load implementation classes.  The context classloader by default has access to 
the app->ext->boot classloader heirarchy.

Pascal, at one point didn't we consider changing ContextFinder to use a parent 
classloader depending on the value of the osgi.parentClassloader property 
(i.e. app, ext, boot etc.)?
